newsitem.title: EGYPT: Egyptian envoy flies to Israel ahead of summit.
newsitem.headline: Egyptian envoy flies to Israel ahead of summit.

text.p: Egyptian President Hosni Mubarak's senior adviser flew to Israel on Friday to pave the way for Mubarak's summit with Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu next week.
Airport sources said the aide, Osama el-Baz, left from a military airport. He did not speak to reporters. It was not clear how long he planned to stay in Israel.

The two leaders are due to meet in Egypt's Red Sea resort of Sharm el-Sheikh on Tuesday in a bid to revive peace talks that have been on hold since Israel started to build a Jewish settlement in East Jerusalem in March.
The government daily newspaper al-Ahram said Netanyahu telephoned Mubarak twice on Thursday to suggest the Sharm el-Sheikh meeting and to agree that Baz should fly to Israel.
Baz, Mubarak's political consultant, was due to meet Israeli officials "to discuss ideas suggested to take the peace process out of the current crisis," al-Ahram said.
Mubarak sent a handwritten message to Netanyahu expressing his worry about the freeze in talks between Israel and the Palestinians and the need to end the crisis, the paper added.

Mubarak has suggested that a six-month Israeli freeze of settlement activity would give peace efforts a boost. Netanyahu has said his government will press ahead with Jewish construction in areas Israel captured in 1967.

Netanyahu's spokesman Shai Bazak said in a statement on Thursday that "the meeting will take place according to a proposal by Mubarak aimed at exchanging ideas...to further the political process in the region".

"There is an Egyptian policy and Egypt is a player. I certainly think there will be an open ear from the Israeli side for the Egyptian ideas," Netanyahu's new foreign policy adviser Uzi Arad told Israel television.
